LOAN AND PROGRAM SUMMARY 
 
Borrower  Republic of the Philippines 
   
The Proposal  A  program  loan  of  $150  million  to  support  the  Government  to 
implement the Microfinance Development Program (MDP). The loan 
will be accompanied by a technical assistance (TA) grant of $500,000.  
   
Rationale  The reduction of poverty is of the highest priority for the Government of 
the Philippines. Poverty rates have declined in the Philippines in the 
past two decades, however, the absolute number of poor people has 
increased to over 26 million. The second Quarter 2005 Social Weather 
Survey reported that economic conditions for the people continue to be 
harsh, as 57% of household heads regard their households as poor, 
and 12% report that their households experienced hunger at least 
once in the last three months. 
 
Access to microfinance services can improve household incomes and 
reduce poverty and vulnerability of the poor. Access to microfinance 
services can help the poor build viable businesses and pursue income-
generating activities. Microfinance is the central strategy for poverty 
reduction in the Philippines under Republic Act 8425 (Social Reform 
and Poverty Alleviation Act) and is an important part of the Medium- 
Term Philippine Development Plan (MTDP) 2004-2010 and the current 
administration’s  10-point  agenda.  Although  the  Philippines  has 
achieved good progress in promoting microfinance, more than two-
thirds of poor households, or 17 million people, still do not have access 
to microfinance services. Critical actions must now be taken to develop 
a  sound  foundation  to  develop  microfinance  further  at  a  much 
substantially  accelerated  pace  in  order  to  achieve  the  national 
outreach and necessary sustainability. 
   
Objectives and  MDP  will  support  the  Government  to  address  the  systemic 
Scope  weaknesses in the sector and achieve the Millennium Development 
  Goals including eradication of extreme poverty and hunger, and the 
promotion of gender equality and empowerment of women. It aims to 
promote  permanent  access  to  sustainable,  competitively-priced 
financial services for the poor and their microenterprises. It is aligned 
with the G-8 Action Plan for poverty reduction, best practices of the 
Consultative  Group  to  Assist  the  Poor  (CGAP),  and  Asian 
Development Bank’s (ADB) Microfinance Development Strategy.  
 
The overall objective of the MDP is to improve household incomes, 
reduce poverty, and reduce vulnerability of the poor. To achieve this 
objective, the MDP will undertake strategic reforms to: 
 
(i)  enhance  the  enabling  policy  and  regulatory  environment  and 
remove regulatory impediments and policy distortions to promote 
market  efficiencies  and  increased  outreach  of  services  at 
competitive prices to the poor;

ii   
(ii) build  viable  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs)  that  can  provide 
efficient and cost-effective retail delivery of services to the poor; 
(iii) strengthen regulatory and supervisory capacities and oversight for 
a sound microfinance sector; and  
(iv) increase financial literacy and consumer protection for the poor 
and users of microfinance services.

I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to the Republic of the Philippines for the Microfinance Development Program (MDP). The report 
also describes technical assistance (TA) to support the implementation of MDP, and if the Board 
approves the proposed loan, I, acting under the authority delegated to me by the Board, shall 
approve the TA. 
 
II.  THE SECTOR 
 
A.  Sector Description and Performance  
   
2.  The Macroeconomic Context. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) Philippine country 
poverty analysis (CPA) for 2005 shows that the Philippines shares the common problem of low-
income countries − high poverty, despite its middle-income status. The overall poverty incident 
was still high at 44.1% in 20031, though it had declined from 53.5% in 1991. The distribution of 
income is highly inequitable. The lowest income quintile accounted for only 4.7% of total income 
in 2003, which was unchanged from 1991. Meanwhile, the highest income quintile accounted for 
53.4% of total income in 2003, compared to 53.9% in 1991. The Gini coefficient2 during the 
same period was unchanged at 0.47, with a narrow fluctuation between 0.45 in 1994 and 0.49 in 
1997. Though the Philippines experienced sustained GDP growth from 2000–2003, preliminary 
2003 Family Income and Expenditure Survey results indicate a 10% drop in real average family 
incomes. Families in the National Capital Region (NCR) suffered an almost 20% drop. The 
sustained economic growth during this period had not been pro-poor. The very high rural 
poverty incidence (47% of families in 2000) has remained unchanged since 1988 (46.3% of 
families). The urban poverty incidence fell from 30.1% of families in 1988 to 19.9% in 2000. 
However, the absolute number of urban poor families grew by 11% nationwide between 1997 
and 2000. There are seven regions where the number of urban poor families grew by more than 
20%. Rural poverty incidence is much more pronounced than urban poverty incidence, but the 
number of urban poor families is increasing. 
 
3.  The  second  quarter  2005  Social  Weather  Stations  survey3  reported  that  economic 
conditions continue to be harsh; 57% of household heads regarded their households as poor, 
and 12% reported that their households experienced hunger at least once in the last 3 months. 
In  the  Medium-Term  Philippine  Development  Plan  (MTDP)  2004–2010,  the  Government 
reported that poverty incidence worsened to 34% in 2000 from 33% in 1997 and the number of 
poor  individuals  increased  from  23.95  million  in  1997  to  26.54  million  in  2000.  With  the 
population growing at 2.36% per year and a projected annual addition of 1.6 million people, a 
heavy burden will be placed on the social and physical infrastructure and the environment. 
Without  corrective  action  to  rebalance  population  growth  against  the  limited  resources, 
prospects are limited for moving the 40% of Filipinos currently living on $2 or less a day out of 
poverty. Even with no change in the population, “access poverty” is a major problem. Poverty is 
manifested in low incomes and in exclusion, including poor access to services. Income poverty 
in the Philippines is a dynamic phenomenon with people moving in and out of poverty over time. 
A survey to gauge chronic and transient poverty found that over a 3-year period about one fifth

4.  Poverty Reduction and Microfinance. The CPA highlights seven major causes of 
poverty: (i) weak macroeconomic management; (ii) employment issues; (iii) high population 
growth rates; (iv) an underperforming agricultural sector and an unfinished land reform agenda; 
(v) governance issues including corruption and a weak state; (vi) conflict and security issues, 
particularly  in  Mindanao;  and  (vii) disability.  The  CPA  also  recognizes  that  poverty  is 
multidimensional, and defines poverty as deprivation of five essential assets, or types of capital: 
 
(i)  human capital (education, good health, skills, and ability to work);  
(ii)  natural capital (natural resource stocks such as land, forested areas, and clean 
air); 
(iii)  physical  capital  (basic  infrastructure  and  services  such  as  shelter,  transport, 
water and sanitation, energy, and communications); 
(iv)  financial capital (earned income, savings, remittances, access to credit); and 
(v)  social capital (social resources such as network of family, friends, and social and 
community organizations). 
 
5.  Access to credit is a form of financial capital. Microfinance credit and services that help 
the poor to receive remittances and build savings safely can also help them gain access to other 
fundamental assets such as education, good health, shelter, and communications. Studies from 
a number of countries have shown that the rural poor’s lack of access to product and factor 
markets leaves them largely bypassed by the growth process. Making markets work for the poor 
is therefore a key element of a country’s poverty reduction strategy.5 This supports the view that 
the poor should be actively engaged in the growth process, as opposed to being left simply to 
share in the benefits of growth (i.e., relying on the trickle-down effects of growth). Microfinance 
can help the poor gain access to product and factor markets, and increase employment and 
income-generating activities, thereby actively engaging them in the growth process.  
 
6.  Supply and Demand of Microfinance Services. Various microfinance services are 
provided in the Philippines by banks, cooperatives, and nongovernment organizations (NGOs), 
including 184 banks6 (rural, thrift and cooperative banks), about 500 NGOs, and 4,579 savings 
and credit cooperatives. Many other types of registered cooperatives also provide some form of 
financial services. In addition, an increasing number of financial institutions are engaging in 
microfinance, while informal and unregulated institutions are moving toward formalization. MFI 
NGOs have played an important role in providing services in hard-to-reach areas where the 
private sector has not entered and where there is less information on the markets and potential 
clients. The number of active borrowers from banks engaged in microfinance was reported by 
BSP at 549,348 as of December 2004. NAPC reports show total borrowers at 2.1 million, 
including bank clients, as of June 2005 based on information reported by government financial 
institutions (GFIs) engaged in wholesale lending to microfinance institutions.  
 
7.  Although the Philippines has achieved significant progress in promoting microfinance, 
more than two-thirds of poor households, or 17 million people, still do not have access to 
microfinance services.7 Instead, the poor rely heavily on self-finance or informal sources that

economic opportunities and income-generating activities, and reduce vulnerability to external 
shocks  or  contingencies.  Microfinance  is  the  central  strategy  for  poverty  reduction  in  the 
Philippines under Republic Act 8425 Social Reform and Poverty Alleviation Act, and is an 
important  part  of  the  MTDP  2004-2010.  However,  despite  Government  commitment  and 
development of the sector to date, further measures are required to meet popular demand, 
achieve  Government’s  goal  of  universal  access  originally  targeted  for  2005,  and  address 
systemic weaknesses in the sector.  
 
8.   Microfinance  encompasses  a  range  of  services  including  savings  deposits,  loans, 
payment services, money transfers, remittances, and insurance. Historically, microfinance has 
concentrated on microcredit designed for high-turnover microenterprises. In practice, however, it 
has been found that clients have adapted the loans for a variety of purposes such as medical 
expenses, funerals, and school fees in addition to funding livelihood activities. Microfinance is 
also  important  for  land  acquisition,  housing  construction,  purchase  of  animals,  consumer 
durables  and  other  items.  Bangko  Sentral  ng  Pilipinas  (BSP)  regulations8  specify  that  the 
maximum principal amount of a microfinance loan shall not exceed P150,000 and, loans are 
often P4,000 and below. Interest rates in the market are high, and it is not uncommon to see 
rates of 60% or more per annum even before additional fees and deductions are taken into 
account.  These  high  rates  of  interest  could  be  reduced  through  competitive  pricing  and 
increased  efficiencies  to  lower  cost  of  borrowing  to  the  poor.  The  clients  of  microfinance 
institutions (MFIs) are broadly the poor and low-income households and their microenterprises.9  
More than 90% of borrowers to date have been women. Who controls the funds once received, 
and how these are managed within the household unit, are areas for further examination. MFI 
clients  typically  lack  assets  for  collateral,  and  are  self-employed  in  the  informal  sector  or 
engaged in economic livelihood activities. Loans are based on the borrower household's net 
cash  flow  and  non-traditional  forms  of  security,  and  may  be  provided  to  either  groups  or 
individuals.10  The microfinance sector as a whole has had very good repayment rates, and this 
is one of the attractive features of this market for financial institutions. The demand for savings 
services is strong as or stronger than the demand for credit, and an expansion of the outreach 
of savings services will be essential for institutional sustainability and poverty reduction.

10.  A  sustainable  microfinance  sector  is  a  core  principle  of  BSP  regulations11  for 
microfinance. BSP regulations require “interest rates to be not lower than prevailing market 
rates” to enable MFIs to recover financial and operational costs. For many years, it was believed 
that the poor were “beneficiaries” of microfinance who were unable to save, that those who did 
save preferred non-financial forms, and that the poor could not afford the full cost of credit at 
commercial rates. This earlier view led to an institutional response that was supply-led and 
focused  on  subsidized  credit  programs  by  governments  and  international  donor  agencies. 
Private financial institutions, therefore, developed a high dependency on external borrowings 
and mobilization of savings was neglected. However, the poor are now viewed as bankable 
“clients” with high loan repayment rates and increasing savings, and provision of finance is 
increasingly demand-driven rather than supply-led. Microfinance is considered to be an integral 
part of a well-functioning financial sector that includes poor people in economic flows and offers 
opportunities that support the growth of local markets. 
 
11.  The Philippine Government recognized that government-funded credit programs were 
costly, inefficient, unsustainable and left many poor still lacking access despite a proliferation of 
programs. Executive Order No. 138 issued in 1999 called for an end to subsidized, directed 
credit programs and the transfer of government-directed credit programs to financial institutions. 
Credit subsidies were recognized as creating market distortions, weakening the rural banking 
system, and adding to the fiscal burden of the Government. DOF reported that as of end 2004, 
most if not all of the direct credit programs have either been terminated or transferred to GFIs 
for continued implementation. Providing subsidized government credit programs could “crowd 
out”  private,  sustainable  microfinance  services,  and  would  run  counter  to  the  NCC  policy 
framework for microfinance.    
 
12.  Although the Philippines is recognized for its microfinance sector, more than two-thirds 
of the 26 million poor, or 17 million people, have no access to it, and the country is still far from 
reaching its goal of providing access to microfinance services for all poor families. Recognizing 
the importance of new entrants and of increased competition in the microfinance sector, BSP 
declared a partial moratorium on restrictions to allow establishment of microfinance-oriented

banks and microfinance lending windows for rural and thrift banks.12  A further relaxation of BSP 
regulations could facilitate more entry and competition. The definition/qualifications for banks to 
be considered “microfinance-oriented” is limited, and restrictions on geographic location and 
fixed percentages of gross loan portfolio impede the expansion of sound financial institutions 
that  could  provide  competitive,  efficient  microfinance  services.  Some  banks  have  also 
established NGOs in order to expand into restricted areas. This involves additional increased 
cost and administrative burden to the MFI and results in expansion of unregulated entities that 
cannot  provide  savings  services.  Increasing  expansion  of  deposit-taking  institutions  in 
microfinance is important not only to provide the savings services needed by the poor, but also 
to build the resources needed for sustainable microfinance. Although opening the sector for 
increased competition may not entirely remove monopolistic pricing, the Consultative Group to 
Assist  the  Poor  (CGAP)  has  shown  that  increased  competition  can  reduce  the  pricing  of 
microfinance services, which is beneficial for the poor.  
 
13.  A lack of standard disclosure practices across MFIs on total costs to the client also 
impedes the development of a robust, competitive environment for microfinance. Although the 
banks  have  established  truth-in-lending  guidelines  and  practices,  there  are  no  equivalent 
guidelines for cooperatives or NGO MFIs. This means that clients may not now the costs of 
borrowing and cannot effectively compare total costs among various providers of microfinance. 
Interest rates can be expressed in a variety of ways that are not transparent and do not reveal 
total costs. Practices vary among MFIs. Interest on microfinance loans, which is usually paid 
once a week, can also be paid daily, monthly, or on another basis depending on the needs and 
cash  flow  capacities  of  clients.  Compulsory  deposits  or  compensatory  balances  and  other 
charges and fees can also significantly increase the effective interest rate on funds borrowed. In 
the banking sector, in 2004 and 2005 BSP required banks operating in microfinance to adopt 
practices  and  modify  truth  in  lending  forms  in  recognition  of  the  special  characteristics  of 
microfinance and the fact that many MFI clients may have limited financial education. However, 
there are no established practices for the cooperative sector or NGO MFIs for truth-in-lending, 
and the majority of organizations are completely unaware of the Truth-in-Lending Act and 
requirements for disclosure to protect borrowers. It is important that standard requirements for 
truth in lending information and disclosure to microfinance clients are established for MFIs. 
 
14.  The tax regime for the microfinance sector is not specified, and there is a need for the 
Bureau  of  Internal  Revenue  (BIR)  to  develop  revenue  regulations  for  clarification  of  tax 
treatment in the sector. Presently, there is not a consistent application or enforcement of tax for 
MFIs within a particular class or type. Because of this uncertainty, there is confusion in the 
sector and some MFIs are deferring development plans pending resolution. Currently, there are 
incentives in the sector for MFIs to operate as NGOs, given the lack of restrictions on opening 
NGO branches, and as they pay no income or gross receipt tax. However, incentives for MFIs to 
operate as unregulated institutions (not authorized to accept deposits), promotes the expansion 
of  institutions  with  limited  sustainability.  This  ultimately  undermines  the  goal  of  achieving 
nationwide  sustainable  microfinance  services  for  the  poor.  The  need  to  commercialize 
microfinance in order to provide sustainable access to financial services is well recognized, and 
is part of the NCC microfinance policy. The profitability of microfinance operations has been 
demonstrated  in  the  Philippines,  and  it  is  important  to  examine  whether  at  this  stage  tax 
exemption for microfinance is needed when the private sector can profitably operate such 
business. In view of the current fiscal crisis in the Philippines, and the Government’s ongoing

  2.  Regulatory and Supervisory Authorities 
 
15.  There is no single regulatory authority for entities providing microfinance services. Thrift 
banks and rural banks are supervised by BSP; credit cooperatives are under the supervision of 
the Cooperative Development Authority (CDA); and microfinance NGOs are not regulated or 
supervised by any government agency. With no single authority, there have been both uneven 
standards and fragmented supervision and regulation across MFIs. The following summarizes 
regulatory and monitoring frameworks for banks, cooperatives and MFI NGOs.  
 
16.  Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP). BSP is the regulatory authority for all banking 
institutions including those engaged in microfinance. BSP recognizes microfinance-oriented 
banks that are licensed, such as normal thrift or rural banks with additional requirements for 
microfinance.  BSP  circulars13  issued  in  2003  prescribe  detailed  reporting  on  microfinance 
operations and provide a formal minimum credit risk management guidelines, including the 
measurement of portfolio-at-risk and provisioning standards. As part of its regulatory mandate, 
BSP supervises and conducts regular examinations of banks. Examiners check for compliance 
with  banking  laws,  rules  and  regulations;  soundness  of  systems  for  evaluating  credit; 
supervision and collection of loans; and the quality of the loan portfolio. Recognizing that 
microfinance operations have special characteristics, in 2005 BSP will adopt a manual for the 
supervision and examination of banks engaged in microfinance operations. Section 40 of the 
General Banking Act of 2000 recognized the special characteristics of microfinance and directed 
the Monetary Board to issue measures for microfinance. In that regard, BSP has issued a series 
of circulars to address microfinance operations and practices, and has reviewed its existing 
regulatory, supervisory and examination procedures and guidelines. More detailed information 
on microfinance operations and performance by thrift and rural banks will be important for 
assessing the sector. In addition, data need to be made more accessible on the BSP website, 
which currently provides limited information on microfinance. 
 
17.  Cooperative  Development  Authority  (CDA).  Established  in  1990,  the  CDA  is 
mandated under the Cooperative Development Authority Republic Act No. 6939 (RA 6939) to 
provide  oversight  functions  for  all  types  of  cooperatives14  including  savings  and  credit 
cooperatives. CDA extension offices are located in the cities of Dagupan, Naga, Iloilo, Cebu, 
Cagayan de Oro, and Davao (Supplementary Appendix B). Credit cooperatives can mobilize 
millions of pesos of deposits from members who are largely from low and middle-income 
groups. In 2003, CDA reported savings of P6.9 billion and capital build-up and P3.5 billion in 
7,840 cooperatives. Some cooperatives are even larger than some rural and thrift banks, and 
there is a need to institute prudential norms and oversight measures to protect cooperative 
members’ deposits. The total number of registered cooperatives in the Philippines reported for 
2003 is 64,998, although the number of operating cooperatives was only 31,191. The large

18.   CDA  registers  cooperatives  and  their  federations  and  unions,  and  requires  all 
registrants to submit annual audited financial statements and general information sheets. CDA 
does not, however, supervise or examine the books of credit cooperatives, and lacks the data 
and management information systems to oversee them effectively. Data are not centralized at 
CDA headquarters or readily available to CDA officers in Manila, which significantly reduce 
CDA’s  oversight  capacity.  Although  CDA  has  the  power  to  cancel  the  registration  of 
cooperatives for non-compliance with administrative requirements, it has not issued prudential 
rules  and  regulations  for  safe  and  sound  operation  of  cooperatives  in  savings  and  credit 
activities. CDA has historically concentrated on development and promotion of cooperatives and 
their products and services, and regulation has been weak because of the conflicting mandates 
of  regulation  and  development,  insufficient  regulatory  power,  and  lack  of  uniform  and 
transparent information on cooperatives. CDA was transferred from the Office of the President 
to  the  DOF  in  2004  to  strengthen  its  regulatory  and  oversight  functions  and  to  facilitate 
coordination of policies and programs between DOF and CDA. Amendments to RA 6939 and 
the Cooperative Code of the Philippines (RA 6938) were prepared by CDA and submitted to 
Congress in 2004. The reorganization of CDA is necessary for providing more focused oversight 
for savings and credit cooperatives. 
 
19.  Cooperatives are a major MFI in the Philippines. Most of the 4,500 credit cooperatives 
and many of the over 18,000 other cooperatives provide microfinance services to their poor 
members. For a sound microfinance operation by the cooperative sector, CDA, in collaboration 
with NCC, has developed a standard chart of accounts (SCA) and performance standards to be 
applied to credit and other types of cooperatives engaged in savings and credit services. The 
remaining challenge is to see these performance standards fully implemented by all financial 
cooperatives. This will need capacity building of cooperatives through training on credit risk 
management,  accounting,  asset-liability  management,  corporate  governance,  and  other 
subjects related to sound financial service operations. CDA is currently standardizing a training 
module on cooperative operations of credit and savings services. Training sessions based on 
the  standard  curriculum  should  be  conducted  at  financial  cooperatives  by  cooperative 
associations and unions accredited by CDA. There should also be training in the SCA and 
performance standards developed by CDA for cooperatives engaged in financial services. Over 
2,500 cooperatives are registered every year. However, the current CDA registration system 
requires  manual  reconciliation  and  verification.  Moreover,  only  15%  of  68,000  registered 
cooperatives (only about 28,000 of which are active) submit annual operational and financial 
status  accounts.  There  is  an  urgent  need  to  modernize  the  CDA  registration  system  and 
improve cooperatives’ compliance with CDA requirements. 
 
20.  Securities  Exchange  Commission  (SEC).  All  NGOs,  including  those  providing 
microfinance, register with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) as non-stock, non-
profit  organizations,  and  are  required  to  file  annual  audited  financial  reports  and  general 
information sheets. Considered to be non-deposit-taking institutions, MFI NGOs are not subject 
to prudential regulation and supervision by any government regulatory authority. In practice, 
NGO MFIs do take “compulsory” deposits (also known as capital build up and compensatory 
balances)  from  borrower-clients.  Under  the  General  Banking  Act,  only  registered  banking 
institutions are allowed to accept deposits from the general public. However, BSP has been 
taking a tolerant view of this practice as long as total deposits of the MFI NGO do not exceed 
total outstanding loan balances. MFI NGOs that collect savings beyond the  compensating 
balance are encouraged to transform themselves into formal, regulated financial institutions

8   
(credit cooperatives or rural or thrift banks). However, there are also concerns that some MFIs 
are illegally accepting individual voluntary deposits. With no effective monitoring mechanism in 
place for monitoring this activity, it is difficult to assess these concerns fully. As these “deposit-
taking” activities involve prudential issues that require regulation, there is a need to resolve this 
matter. At best, MFI NGOs file only annual statements, and as can be seen in the sample of 
SEC documents referenced below, even these reports are not current for many institutions.  An 
effective information reporting system needs to be established if BSP is to oversee voluntary 
deposit-taking properly.     
 
21.  There is a general lack of data for MFI NGOs, and the lack of a current, uniform, and 
transparent set of data for MFI NGOs is a significant issue. The majority of MFI NGOs do not 
use the term “microfinance” to identify their business when registering with SEC, and therefore 
SEC  is  not  able  to  completely  identify  NGOs  that  operate  as  MFIs.  Common  business 
descriptions such as “social development” or “facilitating access to economic development 
activities” are often used. Although these are also indicative of NGO efforts, the failure to 
disclose that an NGO is conducting microfinance lending operations prevents proper oversight 
and governance. A review of the latest filed SEC documents for 15 larger NGO MFIs found that, 
as of 15 May 2005, for 3 their most recent report was 2004, for 7 it was 2003, and for 5 it was 
2002. All of the 15 NGOs were members of the Microfinance Council of the Philippines, Inc. 
(MCPI), but only a few included microfinance as a stated business activity in their articles of 
incorporation. A few others stated that they “facilitated” financial services but did not indicate 
that they directly “provided” financial services, although they were known to be providers of 
microfinance loans. Disclosure in annual information sheets is similarly lacking. One NGO 
amended its articles of incorporation to eliminate “microfinance” from the name of the NGO, 
although it continued to provide microfinance services and to be a member of the MCPI.   
 
22.  To  facilitate  proper  oversight  and  transparency,  articles  of  incorporation  should  be 
amended to include microfinance as an authorized activity if NGOs provide such services.  In 
addition, the annual information sheets, which are in summary form, could be modified to 
include a box to be checked if microfinance activities are being conducted. This would facilitate 
review by SEC and other authorities. MCPI tracks the performance of its members, although 
this information has been limited because submission is voluntary, and data is published 10 
months after year-end. However, there is potential for MCPI to play a stronger role as a center 
for broader data collection on MFIs beyond its membership. MCPI, established in 1997, is a 
network of 34 institutions (26 practitioners, mostly NGOs, and 8 service providers) working 
towards the rapid development of the microfinance industry.15 Membership requirements include 
(i) a mission statement with a vision for the poor; (ii) a minimum of 3,000 clients; (iii) a minimum 
loan portfolio of Php10 million; (iv) a three-year track record; (v) an operations manual and 
management information system (MIS); and (vii) SEC documents.

23.  Limited competition in the microfinance sector has resulted in weak incentives for MFIs 
to build capacity, improve efficiencies, or lower the cost of services to clients. It is known that 
microfinance clients in the Philippines can and do pay high rates for borrowing, and that access 
is more important to the poor than cost. MFI rates are higher than those of other commercial 
lenders because of the high transaction and operating costs for lending and collecting (e.g.,

24.  The development and adoption of sound performance standards, SCA, and disclosure 
and  reporting  practices  will  help  ensure  that  MFIs  are  viable  and  sustainable  allow  the 
performance of different types of MFIs to be compared and evaluated, which is difficult under 
the  current  fragmented  regulatory  framework.  For  the  MFI  NGOs,  MCPI  has  adopted 
performance standards and formulated a SCA, although these have not been widely adopted. 
The chart of accounts is being reviewed to make it comparable with those for other types of 
MFIs. For credit cooperatives and other cooperatives offering savings and credit services, CDA 
has developed a chart of accounts and performance standards.16 It has issued circulars17 
requiring adoption of the SCA and performance standards, and a transitional period of 1 year 
was allowed to enable implementation by 2004. Although there has been some progress, the 
majority of cooperatives have not yet adopted the chart of accounts or performance standards, 
and capacity building will be important if they are to be implemented effectively. In recognition of 
the  need  for  common  standards,  NCC  and  a  technical  working  group  composed  of 
representatives from microfinance practitioners and other stakeholders reviewed the existing set 
of performance standards and formulated a common set to be applied across all types of MFIs.  
NCC announced the common standards in November 2004, and MFI NGOs, cooperatives and 
banks with microfinance operations will move towards adopting these standards.   
 
25.  The institutional capacity of MFIs is a significant constraint on increasing their size and 
enabling sustainable outreach to the poor.18  Major capacity building is needed if management 
is to gain the skills needed. Currently, many MFIs lack basic skills for sustainable, effective, and 
efficient delivery of microfinance services to the poor. Inefficiencies lead to higher operating 
costs and to unnecessarily high interest rates for the poor. Skills need to be developed in 
(i) management, (ii) financial reporting and disclosure, (iii) credit and cash flow analysis, (iv) risk 
management,  (v) performance  monitoring  systems  and  standards  for  MFIs,  and  (vi) best 
practices for sustainable microfinance. Donor assistance, including ADB TA, is helping to build 
MFI capacity and increase social mobilization.19 Longer term support for the rapidly growing 
microfinance industry would benefit from university and training institute programs and the 
consolidation of current training programs and materials in a free national archive.  
 
26.  A credit information bureau (CIB) including microfinance is important infrastructure to 
increase financial transparency and promote a more efficient microfinance sector. In the current 
environment where there is a lack of credit information, many MFIs are reluctant to lend above 
P50,000. There is a gap in supply of loans in the range from P50,000 to P150,000 (maximum 
allowed), not due to a lack of available funds but to institutions’ desire to diversify their portfolios 
and lower their risk. Better credit information could assist MFIs with risk management and help 
to improve the provision of microfinance to clients. With a rapidly expanding microfinance

4.  Financial Literacy, Gender Education, and Consumer Protection 
 
27.  Greater financial literacy among potential microfinance clients is needed to (i) introduce 
the  poor  to  a  formal  or  semiformal,  market-oriented  institutional  environment,  (ii)  promote 
effective access and utilization of microfinance services, and (iii) ensure adequate knowledge of 
rights and obligations of microfinance clients. A national program for financial literacy is needed 
to  achieve  the  nationwide  expansion  of  microfinance  envisioned  in  the  Philippines.  The 
Government also recognizes the importance of educating women on their financial rights within 
families. Although most borrowers from MFIs are women, concerns remain about management 
of funds once they are within the family unit. In addition, single women are not approved for 
loans under some lending methods, unless they can prove that they are head of the household. 
This type of bias, and impact on women’s development needs to be addressed. Significant 
resources will be needed for a comprehensive national program. NAPC, through the Joining 
Arms  Together  Against  Poverty  (KALAHI)21  network,  and  in  coordination  with  concerned 
agencies,  can  provide  an  organizational  framework  for  a  sustainable  national  program. 
Increasing financial literacy is essential if the poor are to be helped to obtain access to financial 
services, and be protected from false and misleading or illegal practices. Such a program 
should include information on the Truth in Lending Act and required disclosure forms, and other 
laws and regulations applicable to microfinance services and products. Insurance is a particular 
area of concern, as the National Economic and Development Authority (NEDA) has discovered 
that  some  MFIs  are  forcing  the  poor  to  purchase  insurance  policies  in  order  to  access 
microfinance  services,  and  selling  insurance  without  proper  license,  authority,  or  actuarial 
valuation/reserves  to  ensure  payment  of  obligations.  The  poor  need  access  to  insurance 
services in a safe and sound system and in accordance with the law.      
 
28.  To strengthen consumer protection for the poor and users of microfinance, relevant laws 
and  regulations  need  to  be  reviewed  to  ensure  consumer  protection  for  the  poor  and 
microfinance  sector,  including  adequate  systems  for  addressing  consumer  complaints.  To 
facilitate a system that is friendly and practical to the poor and to those in rural areas, an 
affordable system for making inquiries, filing complaints, and mediation in rural and provincial 
areas should be established. NAPC, in coordination with the relevant agencies, could lead 
development of a national system to effectively encompass the poor and disadvantaged groups. 
Establishment of a compliance officer in each MFI responsible for compliance of applicable laws 
and regulations is important to ensure sound operations, and to protect the poor and users of 
microfinance services from illegal and unsound practices. Designation of an officer in the MFI to 
be the compliance officer will not raise the operating overhead costs of the MFI, but will ensure 
sound and sustainable operations.

5.  Savings Mobilization, Remittances, and New Technologies  
 
29.  Mobilization of savings is essential for sustainable national microfinance. Historically, the 
dependence of MFIs on subsidized credits from the Government, donors, and lending agencies 
led to weak savings mobilization. As MFI’s savings deposits increase, so does the pool of 
resources  for  MFIs  to  improve  services  and  expand  outreach.  The  NCC  strategy  for 
microfinance has turned away from promotion of subsidized credits towards mobilization of 
savings deposits. Allowing banks to expand and open branches will help to mobilize savings. 
One potential source for rapid mobilization of savings in the Philippines is remittances from 
overseas Filipino workers (OFWs). Money transfers and remittance services are important to 
many poor, although many have no access to such services through formal channels. Instead 
they rely on informal channels such as physical transportation of cash across borders and other 
methods. BSP reported $8.6 billion in overseas Filipino workers remittances to the Philippines 
through formal channels in 2004. An equal, or even greater amount, is considered by some to 
be channeled through informal channels into the Philippines. If MFIs could capture 5% of the 
informal remittance flows, this would translate into $430 million. Capturing 15% of informal 
remittance flows would translate into $1.29 billion. A large portion of such remittances would go 
to a variety of household and family expenditures, but the remainder could remain in an MFI 
deposit account rather than at home or at a neighbor’s for safekeeping.

30.  To facilitate the depositing of remittances directly into the accounts of regulated deposit-
taking MFIs (rural banks, thrift banks, credit and savings cooperatives), a regulatory framework 
is  needed.  Enabling  these  sectors  to  capture  informal  remittance  flows,  could  significantly 
increase MFI savings deposits and provide a vital service to the poor. It could accelerate the 
expansion and outreach of sustainable microfinance and lower the cost of loans to the poor. 
The cost of funds raised through savings mobilization is significantly lower that the cost of funds 
provided to MFIs by government financial institutions for onlending. Not only does savings 
mobilization provide resources for sustainable national outreach of microfinance services—it 
ultimately lowers the cost of credit to the poor. 
 
31.  New cell-phone-based technologies can also significantly lower the cost of remittances 
and money transfers into deposit accounts. The Philippines is the international leader in this 
area, and is rapidly adapting products and services to meet the needs of OFWs and the public. 
Regulations are needed to support the transfer of remittances into deposit accounts of regulated 
MFIs using cell-phone-based technology. Clear rules are needed for MFIs to be approved as

remittance centers. Specific regulations are needed for centers that receive remittances only in 
pesos (and therefore do not need a foreign exchange facility). The Philippines is in a unique 
position to establish best practice guidelines and regulations for cell phone technology that 
could provide a global model. 
 
32.  An  estimated  43%  of  Filipinos,  or  36  million  people,  use  cellular  phones  and  the 
penetration rate is expected to increase by year-end 2005. A used cell phone can be purchased 
for as low as P500, and a SIM card/phone number can be purchased for around P200–P300, 
enabling cell phone access to many persons. Entrepreneurs with cell phones are also providing 
payment services to persons without cell phones or living in remote areas without cellular 
service. This is an important service for microentrepreneurs living in remote areas who can not 
afford the time to personally visit an MFI to make loan payments, but have the capacity to repay. 
Payment by cell phone could result in a savings of 6–8 hours that could be used for productive 
work in the microenterprise or livelihood activity. One service provider’s tie-up arrangement with 
the Rural Bankers Association of the Philippines (RBAP) and the Microenterprise Access to 
Banking Services Program (MABS),22 helps to facilitate disbursement and collection of loans via 
cell phone. The National Confederation of Cooperatives, Inc. (NATCCO) has also aligned with a 
service provider to enhance loan services  and implement livelihood programs  for member 
cooperatives. The outreach opportunities for transfer and payment services are great, and the 
developments underway for an alliance among major mobile operators in the Asia-Pacific that 
will  support  regional  mobile  infrastructure  for  a  common  service  platform  that  will  allow 
seamless cross-border services.23 Remittances via cell phones are expected to gain significant 
market share especially in rural areas with weak financial infrastructure.

33.  Significant external assistance has been provided by funding agencies and donors to the 
Philippines for the microfinance sector. ADB assistance will complement this assistance, and 
build upon sector developments and progress to date. ADB will continue coordination with 
agencies during the implementation of the MDP to ensure effective allocation of resources and 
coordination among agencies active in this sector. Sector projects include the United States 
Agency  for  International  Development  (USAID)-funded  programs⎯MABS,  Credit  Policy 
Improvement Program (CPIP), and the Credit Union Empowerment and Strengthening Program 
II  (CUES-II).  The  German  Agency  for  Technical  Cooperation  (GTZ)  Small  and  Medium 
Enterprise Program provides capacity building for financial institutions and a training program 
for SME lending for privately owned rural banks, and thrift banks in the Visayas region. The 
Microfinance Sector Strengthening Project (MSSP) funded by the United Nations Development 
Programme  (UNDP)  and  the  Australian  Agency  for  International  Development  (AusAID) 
provides technical assistance including training to MFIs on the ASA methodology of individual

includes access to the Canada Fund for Local Initiatives and the Private Enterprise Accelerated

7.  Lessons Learned 
 
34.  The Philippines’ country assistance program evaluation (CAPE)24 noted that ADB can 
play a pivotal role in helping the Philippines to reduce poverty and promote social development, 
and that ADB’s future lending operations can focus on such areas as microcredit to support 
income-generating  activities  of  the  poor.  It  was  also  noted  that  emphasis  should  be  on 
sustainability rather than the speed of implementation of reforms, recognizing the limitations that 
can arise from stakeholder consultation and democratic process. The CAPE included two NGO 
microcredit projects25 approved in 1988 and 1991, and noted the success of the projects in 
creating income-generating activities of the poor. ADB’s experience in microcredit lending has 
heightened staff awareness of a number of important project design features. Reaching the very 
poor, particularly in the Philippine context, requires a high degree of social preparation of 
targeted beneficiaries who are identified by a means test. Microenterprises, like any other 
business, need continuous access to reasonably priced credit for sustainability and expansion. 
The Rural Microenterprise Finance Project,26 approved in 1996, was based on findings of a 
number of evaluations of microcredit programs that showed: (i) subsidized loans provided to 
end-borrowers at below market rates encouraged corruption and often reached the local elite 
rather than target groups of lower-income borrowers; (ii) credit subsidies provided at the local 
level frequently discouraged institutional savings mobilization; (iii) where microcredit had been 
provided  by  institutions  at  commercial  interest  rates,  and  where  local  savings  have  been 
mobilized, loans tended to be widely available and repayment rates high; and (iv) when credit 
subsidies were replaced by commercial microfinance, there could be substantial savings to 
governments and funding sources. Lessons learned27 from ADB’s microfinance operations are 
similar to those learned by other funding agencies and those reported in the CGAP guidelines 
and papers. 
 
(i)  The financial system approach is the key to achieving sustainable results and to 
maximizing development impact. This approach emphasizes an enabling policy 
environment,  financial  infrastructure,  and  financial  intermediaries  that  are 
committed to achieving financial viability and sustainability within a reasonable 
period and that can provide a variety of financial services, not just credit, to the 
poor. 
 
(ii)  Microfinance  clients  are  more  concerned  about  access  to  services  that  are 
compatible with their requirements than about the cost of services, and, given the 
diversity of demand for financial services, a broad range of institutional types is 
required. 
 
(iii)  Strong retail institutions committed to outreach and sustainability are essential for 
permanently extending the reach of financial services and having a significant 
impact  on  poverty  reduction.  Financial  institutions  committed  to  providing 
microfinance services in most developing member countries require considerable 
TA for capacity building.

III.  THE PROPOSED PROGRAM 
 
A.   Objectives and Scope 
 
35.  The goal of the MDP is to assist Government to reduce poverty and promote sustainable 
economic growth. The MDP supports the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) of eradicating 
extreme poverty and hunger, promoting gender equality and empowering women. The MDP will 
contribute to these goals by achieving its objective of ensuring permanent access to sustainable 
institutional  financial  services  for  a  majority  of  poor  and  low-income  households  and  their 
microenterprises at competitive prices. A national financial literacy program, including gender 
training and consumer protection, will empower the poor and promote effective access and 
utilization of microfinance services. MDP will assist the Government to build viable MFIs , and 
improve  the  performance  of  the  microfinance  sector,  including  reducing  transaction  costs 
associated with delivery of financial services and thereby increase sustained access to financial 
services by the poor. The poor will have opportunities to increase incomes and employment and 
improve their quality of life through access to sustainable and more responsive microfinance 
services  including  money  transfer  and  remittance  services  that  support  investment  and 
production.28  A Design and Monitoring Framework is included in Appendix 2.

58.  The poor will benefit from improved efficiencies and performance of service providers 
that can provide more cost-effective retail delivery of services on a sustainable basis. Sustained 
access  to  microfinance  services  will  enable  the  poor  to  build  viable  businesses,  pursue 
economic  opportunities  and  income-generating  activities,  and  reduce  their  vulnerability  to 
shocks and contingencies. Microenterprises will be able to expand, benefiting owners and their 
families directly and the broader economy indirectly through increased economic activity.      
 
59.  The removal of regulatory impediments to competition and barriers to expansion by 
financially sound and well-managed microfinance institutions will result in a more robust and 
competitive environment that will increase the outreach of MFIs and the range of available 
services, and lower the cost of services to the poor. The poor will benefit from the introduction of 
truth-in-lending to all types of MFIs for full disclosure of costs of borrowing and transparency in 
transactions.

the microfinance sector will stimulate investment in the sector, bringing strategic resources and

SECTOR ANALYSIS 
 
1.  Various microfinance services are provided in the Philippines by banks, cooperatives, and 
nongovernment organizations (NGOs), including 184 banks1 (rural, thrift and cooperative banks), 
about 500 NGOs, and 4,579 savings and credit cooperatives. Many other types of registered 
cooperatives also provide some form of financial services. In addition, an increasing number of 
financial institutions are engaging in microfinance, while informal and unregulated institutions are 
moving toward formalization. MFI NGOs have played an important role in providing services in 
hard-to-reach areas where the private sector has not entered and where there is less information 
on the markets and potential clients. The number of active borrowers from banks engaged in 
microfinance was reported by BSP at 549,348 as of December 2004. NAPC reports show total 
borrowers at 2.1 million, including bank clients, as of June 2005 based on information reported by 
government financial institutions engaged in wholesale lending to microfinance institutions.  
 
2.  Although the Philippines has achieved significant progress in promoting microfinance, more 
than two-thirds of poor households, or 17 million people, still do not have access to microfinance 
services.2  Instead, the poor rely heavily on self-finance or informal sources that may be very 
costly, limiting their ability to participate in and benefit from development opportunities and income-
generating activities. The limited outreach of microfinance services is reported in the National Anti-
Poverty  Commission  (NAPC)  2004  report,  Status  of  Microfinance  Outreach  in  60  Poorest 
Provinces, which details outreach, potential number of client households, and saturation level of 
microfinance services in each area.  Access to microfinance services can help the poor build viable 
businesses,  pursue  economic  opportunities  and  income-generating  activities,  and  reduce 
vulnerability to external shocks or contingencies. Microfinance is the central strategy for poverty 
reduction in the Philippines under Republic Act 8425 Social Reform and Poverty Alleviation Act, 
and is an important part of the Medium Term Philippines Development Plan (MTDP) 2004-2010.   
However,  despite  Government  commitment  and  development  of  the  sector  to  date,  further 
measures are required to meet popular demand, achieve Government’s goal of universal access 
originally targeted for 2005, and address systemic weaknesses in the sector.  
 
3.   Microfinance encompasses a range of services including savings deposits, loans, payment 
services, money transfers, remittances, and insurance. Historically, microfinance has concentrated 
on microcredit designed for high-turnover microenterprises. In practice, however, it was found that 
clients also adapted the loans for a variety of purposes such as medical expenses, funerals, and 
school fees in addition to funding livelihood activities. Microfinance is also important for land 
acquisition,  housing  construction,  purchase  of  animals,  consumer  durables  and  other  items. 
Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas (BSP) regulations3 specify that the maximum principal amount of a 
microfinance loan shall not exceed P150,000, however loans are often in the amount of  P4,000 
and below. Interest rates in the market are high, and it is not uncommon to see rates of 60% or 
more  per  annum.  High  rates  of  interest  could  be  reduced  through  competitive  pricing  and 
increased efficiencies to lower cost of borrowing to the poor. MFI clients are broadly the poor and 
low-income households and their microenterprises,4 however more than 90% of borrowers to date 
have been women. Who controls the funds once received, and how these are managed within the 
household  unit  are  areas  for  further  examination.    The  MFI  clients  typically  lack  assets  for

a net worth of P19 billion, and a net income of P1.9 billion. The nonperforming loan ratio was 
10.84%. DBP operates with 77 branches nationwide. It links with commercial banks, thrift banks 
and rural banks for its wholesale lending programs. Its main clients are SMEs, most of which are 
engaged in manufacturing and agricultural processing. 
4.  Small Business Guarantee and Finance Corporation (SBGFC) 
10.  The  Small  Business  Guarantee  and  Finance  Corporation  (SBGFC)  is  a  government 
corporation established in 1991 under the Magna Carta for Small Enterprises (RA 6977), to provide 
Government support to SMEs. It provides wholesale lending, direct lending, and credit guarantee 
services to the SME sector. In 2001, SBGFC merged with the Guarantee Fund for Small and 
Medium Enterprises, a guarantee fund operated by the Livelihood Corporation and attached to the 
Office of the President. Subscribed and paid-up capital as of the end of 2003 amounted to P1.8 
billion, contributed by five government financial institutions (GFIs) and the national Government. 
11.  SBGFC, having been created by an act of Congress, is not registered with the Securities 
and Exchange Commission and is not under its supervision or regulation. However, as it is an 
affiliate of three commercial banks, SBGFC is audited by the Commission on Audit and examined 
by BSP. It is under the direct supervision of the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI). The 
Barangay Microenterprise and Business Enterprises Act of 2002 mandated SBGFC to undertake 
microfinance operations. Its microfinance loan portfolio through 12 cooperatives amounted to P40 
million as of the end of 2003. Its lending rates to MFIs are the same as those under the SME 
Unified Lending Opportunities for National Growth (SULONG) program, which are revised quarterly. 
The current rates are: 9.5% per annum for up to 1 year; 13.8% per annum for 1-3 years; and 14.5% 
per annum for 3-5 years.

billion, net worth of P2.0 billion, and a net income for the year of P42 million. The nonperforming 
loan  ratio  of  SBGFC’s  wholesale  lending  facilities  as  of  December  2003  was  14.35%.  The 
aggregate nonperforming loan ratio of direct loans was 15.95%. SBGFC has a head office in Makati 
City, Metro Manila, one branch each in the Visayas and Mindanao, and two representative offices in

Contribution of the sector/subsector to reduce poverty in the Philippines: 
 
Microfinance is recognized as the central strategy for poverty reduction in the Philippines under Republic 
Act 8425 Social Reform and Poverty Alleviation Act passed in 1997. It is also an important part of 
President  Arroyo’s  10-point  agenda  which  calls  for  the  creation  of  10  million  new  jobs,  and  the 
Philippine’s Medium Term Development Plan (MTDP) 2004-2010 which includes microfinance as a main 
strategy and proven effective tool in alleviating poverty. The G-8 Action Plan for poverty reduction 
includes expanding access to microfinance for entrepreneurs1 and working with the Consultative Group to 
Assist the Poor (CGAP)2 to promote best practices in microfinance for developing countries. Ensuring 
permanent access to institutional financial services for poor and low-income households at competitive 
prices is a goal of ADB’s Microfinance Development Strategy3, and microfinance is a priority in the 
Philippines Country and Strategy Program (CSP) 2005-2007. 
 
Microfinance  clients  are  broadly  the  poor  and  low-income  households  and  their  microenterprises. 
Microfinance encompasses a range of services including savings deposits, loans, payment services, 
money  transfers,  and  insurance.  Access  to  microfinance  services  can  help  the  poor  build  viable 
businesses, pursue economic opportunities and income-generating activities, and reduce vulnerability to 
external shocks or contingencies. Improved access and efficient provision of services can enable the poor 
to smoothen their consumption, manage their risks better, build assets, develop microenterprises, and 
enhance their income-earning capacity.  
 
 
B.  Poverty Analysis                                       Proposed Classification: Targeted intervention 
 
The Government reported in the Medium Term Development Plan (MTDP) 2004-2010 that poverty 
incidence worsened to 34 % in 2000 from 33 % in 1997 and the number of poor individuals increased 
from 23.95 million in 1997 to 26.54 million in 2000. With population growing at 2.36% per year in the 
Philippines, heavy burdens will be placed on the social and physical infrastructure and environment with a 
projected annual addition of 1.6 million people. Without corrective action to rebalance population growth 
against the limited resources, prospects are limited for moving out of poverty the 40% of Filipinos 
currently living on $2 or less a day. Even with no change in population, “access poverty” is a major 
problem in the Philippines. Poverty is manifested in low incomes and in exclusion, including poor access 
to services which keeps the poor vulnerable. Income poverty in the Philippines is a dynamic phenomenon 
with people moving in and out of poverty over time. A survey designed to gauge chronic and transient 
poverty found that over a 3-year period about one fifth of the surveyed households were chronically poor, 
whereas almost one third of the households moved in and out of poverty over the period. 4

D.  Gender Development 
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
To date, more than 90% of borrowers in the microfinance sector have been women. Who controls the 
funds  once  received,  how  the  funds  are  managed  within  the  household  unit,  who  controls  the 
microenterprises and income generated are all areas that need further examination in determining the full 
impacts and potential benefits for women. The National Anti-Poverty Commission (NAPC) has taken a 
proactive role in furthering gender education for women in the Philippines, and launched an initial Gender 
In Microfinance Training Seminar in 2005 to address some of these issues. The strategy under the 
Microfinance Development Program (MDP) is to combine the gender training with the planned national 
financial literacy program to attain maximum outreach and education.

II. Grant Development Objective(s) and Expected Key Performance Indicators 
Grant Development Objectives (GDO): The ADB Philippine Country Strategy and Program (CSP) 2005–
2007 identifies development of microfinance as one of the key strategies for more rapid poverty reduction. 
Microfinance is recognized as the central strategy for poverty reduction in the Philippines under Republic 
Act 8425 Social Reform and Poverty Alleviation Act. Ensuring permanent access to institutional financial 
services for poor and low-income households at competitive prices is also a goal of ADB’s Microfinance 
Development Strategy. ADB is currently formulating the Philippine Microfinance Development Program, 
which aims at developing sustainable Philippine microfinance industry in line with the CSP. To complement 
the Program, the proposed JFPR assistance aims to support the development of financial cooperatives and 
strengthen institutional capacity and efficiencies of the Cooperative Development Authority (CDA) which 
oversees financial cooperatives in order to provide sustainable microfinance services to the poor. 
 
As a major part of the Philippines’ microfinance sector, financial cooperatives need to develop sound 
financial operations for the members. The Project aims to promote healthy development of the sustainable 
microfinance  industry  in  the  Philippines  to  increase  household  incomes,  reduce  poverty  and  reduce 
vulnerability of the poor to shocks by improving performance of financial cooperatives through capacity 
building and strengthening their compliance with CDA’s regulatory requirement and operating efficiencies. 
 
The Project comprises the following 2 components: 
•  The operations of savings and credit cooperatives will be strengthened by training sessions conducted 
by cooperative federations accredited by CDA, which will standardize the training module on sound 
microfinance operations based on the international best practices. (Component A). 
•  The  performance  monitoring  capacities  of  CDA  will  be  improved  by  the  installation  of  advanced 
registration/management information system (Component B).

•  Improve and standardize the training module on cooperative microfinance operations 
•  Disseminate the CDA performance standards to financial cooperatives
